lines.line_text: 'TWAS at the silent, solemn hour,
When night and morning meet;
In glided MARGARET's grimly ghost,
And stood at WILLIAM's feet.

stanzas.stanza_text:
'TWAS at the silent, solemn hour,
When night and morning meet;
In glided MARGARET's grimly ghost,
And stood at WILLIAM's feet.

lines.line_text: Her face was like an April-morn,
Clad in a wintry cloud:
And clay-cold was her lilly-hand,
That held her sable shroud.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Her face was like an April-morn,
Clad in a wintry cloud:
And clay-cold was her lilly-hand,
That held her sable shroud.

lines.line_text: So shall the fairest face appear,
When youth and years are flown:
Such is the robe that kings must wear,
When death has rest their crown.

stanzas.stanza_text:
So shall the fairest face appear,
When youth and years are flown:
Such is the robe that kings must wear,
When death has rest their crown.

lines.line_text: Her bloom was like the springing flower,
That sips the silver dew;
The rose was budded in her cheek,
Just opening to the view.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Her bloom was like the springing flower,
That sips the silver dew;
The rose was budded in her cheek,
Just opening to the view.

lines.line_text: But love had, like the canker-worm,
Consum'd her early prime:
The rose grew pale, and left her cheek;
She dy'd before her time.

stanzas.stanza_text:
But love had, like the canker-worm,
Consum'd her early prime:
The rose grew pale, and left her cheek;
She dy'd before her time.

lines.line_text: Awake! she cry'd, thy true love calls,
Come from her midnight-grave;
Now let thy pity hear the maid,
Thy love refus'd to save.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Awake! she cry'd, thy true love calls,
Come from her midnight-grave;
Now let thy pity hear the maid,
Thy love refus'd to save.

lines.line_text: This is the dumb and dreary hour,
When injur'd ghosts complain;
When yawning graves give up their dead,
To haunt the faithless swain.

stanzas.stanza_text:
This is the dumb and dreary hour,
When injur'd ghosts complain;
When yawning graves give up their dead,
To haunt the faithless swain.

lines.line_text: Bethink thee, WILLIAM, of thy fault,
Thy pledge and broken oath:
And give me back my maiden-vow,
And give me back my troth.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Bethink thee, WILLIAM, of thy fault,
Thy pledge and broken oath:
And give me back my maiden-vow,
And give me back my troth.

lines.line_text: Why did you promise love to me,
And not that promise keep?
Why did you swear my eyes were bright,
Yet leave those eyes to weep?

stanzas.stanza_text:
Why did you promise love to me,
And not that promise keep?
Why did you swear my eyes were bright,
Yet leave those eyes to weep?

lines.line_text: How could you say my face was fair,
And yet that face forsake?
How could you win my virgin heart,
Yet leave that heart to break?

stanzas.stanza_text:
How could you say my face was fair,
And yet that face forsake?
How could you win my virgin heart,
Yet leave that heart to break?

lines.line_text: Why did you say, my lip my sweet,
And made the scarlet pale?
And why did I, young witless maid,
Believe the flattering tale!

stanzas.stanza_text:
Why did you say, my lip my sweet,
And made the scarlet pale?
And why did I, young witless maid,
Believe the flattering tale!

lines.line_text: That face, alas! no more is fair;
Those lips no longer red:
Dark are my eyes, now clos'd in death,
And every charm is fled.

stanzas.stanza_text:
That face, alas! no more is fair;
Those lips no longer red:
Dark are my eyes, now clos'd in death,
And every charm is fled.

lines.line_text: The hungry worm my sister is;
This winding sheet I wear:
And cold and weary lasts our night,
Till that last morn appear.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The hungry worm my sister is;
This winding sheet I wear:
And cold and weary lasts our night,
Till that last morn appear.

lines.line_text: But hark! the cock has warn'd me hence;
A long and late adieu!
Come, see, false man, how low she lies,
Who dy'd for love of you.

stanzas.stanza_text:
But hark! the cock has warn'd me hence;
A long and late adieu!
Come, see, false man, how low she lies,
Who dy'd for love of you.

lines.line_text: The lark sung loud; the morning smil'd,
With beams of rosy red:
Pale WILLIAM quak'd in every limb,
And raving left his bed.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The lark sung loud; the morning smil'd,
With beams of rosy red:
Pale WILLIAM quak'd in every limb,
And raving left his bed.

lines.line_text: He hy'd him to the fatal place
Where MARGARET's body lay:
And stretch'd him on the grass-green turf,
That wrap'd her breathless clay.

stanzas.stanza_text:
He hy'd him to the fatal place
Where MARGARET's body lay:
And stretch'd him on the grass-green turf,
That wrap'd her breathless clay.

lines.line_text: And thrice he call'd on MARGARET's name,
And thrice he wept full sore:
Then laid his cheek to her cold grave,
And word spoke never more!

stanzas.stanza_text:
And thrice he call'd on MARGARET's name,
And thrice he wept full sore:
Then laid his cheek to her cold grave,
And word spoke never more!
